item.description:
@KWiersoAgain @mjs_DC @Slate This is how secession begins. Texas demands that its hitherto unconstitutional laws be enforced in California. California refuses. The Feds take Texas’ side. Corporations decide the prefer Blue America with its respect for the rule of law, and there you are.
@KWiersoAgain @mjs_DC @Slate Which would explain the brand new National Review / Tikvah Fund / et al open letter defending “The rule of law” without naming who it was subtweeting.

I wonder who was the person at AIPAC who decided that “Zionism is anti-progressivism” was a great message to propagate. I’m old enough to remember when such talk was considered antisemitic. Seems suboptimal, as they say. https://t.co/WgWD3S34Du
Speaking of the intellectual and moral honesty of the Tikvah Fund family. https://t.co/v6q4fjVjtj
Certainly a narrative well crafted to appeal to a German publisher. https://t.co/opqZuiLVf4

This is the grim future Jared Kushner and the Republicans wanted — and the Democrats are too lilly-livered to fight against. https://t.co/DuCpHNc4Kw
Funny how the “Problem solver caucus” couldn’t push for more covid relief.

@JewishWonk This may actually be a criminal offense of “harassment” under NJ law. Might be one in NY too if that’s where you are these days. Might be fun to find a local prosecutor with free time and political ambitions willing to prosecute.
@JewishWonk Here’s my thread with the NJ law, which I stumbled across while working on a story about @ORAAgunot. Picketing a get refuser politely does *not* constitute harassment according to the court ruling I reviewed, but the purpose was not to “annoy” the refuser.
@ImTheQ Reminiscent of an old proposal for Mideast peace that is equally needed on these shores. https://t.co/eRJVrIl3ki
It looks like The Tikvah Fund’s Contragate perjurer shares more than politics with the governor of Florida: Total disdain for telling the truth. https://t.co/KB1hf3AzfI
Fitting tribute to Republican Orrin Hatch in the wake of his recent death. https://t.co/1clSHFxJI0

@onthemainline Wow! Never knew that Ruth Wisse tried her hand at songwriting!
@onthemainline Really amazing use of yeshivish for a song ostensibly addressing someone outside the community.
@onthemainline Mr Carter?
@rmneiss Classic policy of Focus on the Family, ally of Tikvah Fund house rabbi Meir S.

@EladNehorai Conversely, if this pleases you, DM us and we'll tell you what life is actually like for kids in a totalitarian religious community. Particularly for those whose parents did grow up in such themselves.

@joshtpm @wealth I find it hard to believe that Twitter’s obvious failures as an advertising platform is the blame of its ad director rather than something more substantial in its corporate makeup.
@joshtpm @wealth However, exiting him now with an NDA might delay the new owner’s ability to fire the culprit until their options vest.

@mjs_DC @Slate I just stumbled across NJ’s harassment law, which would appear to (lightly) criminalize social media harassment such as posting antisemitic memes of ovens and the like that are designed to annoy Jews. Might that offer a safe haven for social media companies to enforce their TOS?
@mjs_DC @Slate Link to the criminal code. https://t.co/lz0tPRFHVd
@twcravens @Lexaphus Your occasional reminder that the Tzadik of Newark was said to have confused the yetzer hara…. by giving in without a struggle.
@frumfollies @heyBimBam Like I said, I’m not looking for the big bucks. I think I can bootstrap a couple cool projects for relative bupkis.
@AmySpiro https://t.co/qyTTR65nDn
@SamAdlerBell “Why does that question matter to you?”

What’s fascinating is that this “philanthropist” is spending $50 million over a decade to do what the ADL does, but somehow differently, without being able to articulate how. https://t.co/sz4HShq2J5
Maybe I’m cynical about the pliability of Jewish organizations, but I bet if I offered them that sum of money to try a new approach — say, pursuing social media harassers under state law — they wouldn’t turn down the money.
Conversely, if I wanted them to adopt a policy inconsistent with their approach — say, seeking a constitutional amendment to repeal the First Amendment — then I would be willing to proclaim my disagreement.
Which is to say, while this is certainly good for Mr Kraft’s ego, it’s hard to believe this is the optimal use of this money to fight antisemitism, let alone to help the Jewish people.
Note that this sum of money would suffice to bring back @heyBimBam’s project of Jewish educational YouTube videos and fund it for a generation.
Note that half of what YouTube returns right now for a search on “Passover״ are produced by Christian ministries. https://t.co/R2TJ3qo3MG
Finally, while @heyBimBam was a $600k/year operation that probably needed a bit more to be sustainable, I have some exciting print-based ideas for Jewish publishing that could launch with $10k. My dms are open.

Some further thoughts on this (with the reminder that I am not, it should be obvious, a lawyer, though I did cosplay one for years as a yeshiva student). https://t.co/ImSRmh8lSd
Under New Jersey law, it seems that what #onhere think of as antisemitic harassment is in fact a criminal offence. At least according to my amateur reading of NJ Code of Criminal Justice 2C:33-4. https://t.co/XS68wZPMqb
2C:33-4. Harassment.
...a person commits a petty disorderly persons offense if, with purpose to harass another, he:
a. Makes, or causes to be made, a communication or communications anonymously or at extremely inconvenient hours, or in offensively coarse language, or any other manner likely to cause annoyance or alarm;
Fair to say that most of what talk about as harassment is indeed designed to cause annoyance and alarm.
So there is actually a reasonable overlap between Twitter's TOC and this criminal offense.
So Twitter can legally continue to police hate speech (which uses words chosen to cause annoyance) and harassment. At least as far as New Jersey user is involved.
Also worth noting that the court ruling I am currently reading for other purposes dismisses a claim under this statute for a peaceful protest outside the plaintiff's parents' residence. So annoyance here does not mean simply, "I don't want this speaker in my general vicinity."
@kampeas You should ask her about yesterday’s Texas court ruling, apparently banning social media moderation of hateful viewpoints.
First pot, now folk songs. Is @eddyportnoy dragging @yivoinstitute into the 60s? https://t.co/XtS8AGuqzj

@Foone And yet I’m watching Trek on a PADD. Related: At the beginning of Star Trek: Nemesis, Picard has a pile of iPads on his desk, apparently because the intranet is down and there is no way to get staff reports onto his pad.
@Lexaphus I think you should strongly consider turning your rabbinate into one of hosting monthly themed Shabbat dinners.
